Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Rhinoceros Auklet (Cerorhinca Monocerata) Chick Diet and Growth on Teuri Island, Japan and Southeast Farallon Island, United States

POR.DRECONTENT:
The marine environment is an integral part of the earth’s ecosystem as a whole, but it is difficult to monitor because of its large size and conditions that vary over time. It is beneficial to examine the health of species which are directly affected by it in order to make inferences about its condition. Seabirds, being long-lived and dependent on the timing of the marine environment to raise their chicks, are perfect candidates to be environmental indicators. One such species, the Rhinoceros Auklet, spans the Pacific Rim from Japan around to central California, and is a football-sized diving seabird that nests in burrows to breed.

            The objectives of this study were to assess the breeding success and diet composition of Rhinoceros Auklets on Teuri Island off Hokkaido in Japan, and on the Farallones off California in the United States. This was accomplished by weighing a subset of chicks in natural burrows and boxes on Teuri throughout the season to assess their growth and fledging success, and by taking diet samples of adult birds bringing whole fish back to their chicks to assess diet composition and amount. Similar data was taken by researchers affiliated with PRBO Conservation Science on the Farallon Islands over the same breeding period.

            Although many analyses remain to be performed on the data, some general outcomes can be drawn. Egg-laying rate, proportion of chicks hatched, and proportion of chicks fledged were all higher on Southeast Farallon Island (SEFI) than on Teuri. Likewise, the diet composition was different. On SEFI, the adults switched from bringing juvenile rockfish to mainly Pacific saury and sablefish, whereas on Teuri, they switched to anchovy. This may be a result of different sampling plans in each location. It could also result from oceanic conditions such as sea surface temperature, which remains to be found for SEFI for this season. Yet another issue could be that the population on Teuri is greater than that on SEFI, and it might have reached its limit in the resources available.

            This project had great intellectual merit. Although the data collected are not unique, they are part of long-term monitoring studies in both locations which are essential to understanding the ecology of the focal species in its environment, and by extension the ocean as a whole. Long-lived species exhibit high variation in their breeding between years, and seabirds sometimes don’t breed at all if conditions are unfavorable. This information can be used for management of future conservation of the species. Additionally, there has only been one paper assessing the synchrony of breeding in this species across the Pacific. While it covered the concept well over many years, this project will serve to strengthen the previous paper and lay the groundwork for further collaborations in the future. This holistic approach to scientific work is important to the future of the field. Both Japan and the United States have been doing long-term seabird studies, but there have been few combined efforts to compare notes. This project makes it clear that other colonies in Japan and Russia should be studied and compared to the east side of the Pacific in order to better understand this species and their environment as a whole. Thus, this study melds oceanographic and biological concepts across a large area, unlike previous studies which have often focused in small localized ones.

            The broader impacts of this study were mainly cultural in nature. Since the methods in collecting data were similar in both places, there was not a lot to learn in that regard, but working across a language ...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The marine environment is an integral part of the earthÆs ecosystem as a whole, but it is difficult to monitor because of its large size and conditions that vary over time. It is beneficial to examine the health of species which are directly affected by it in order to make inferences about its condition. Seabirds, being long-lived and dependent on the timing of the marine environment to raise their chicks, are perfect candidates to be environmental indicators. One such species, the Rhinoceros Auklet, spans the Pacific Rim from Japan around to central California, and is a football-sized diving seabird that nests in burrows to breed. The objectives of this study were to assess the breeding success and diet composition of Rhinoceros Auklets on Teuri Island off Hokkaido in Japan, and on the Farallones off California in the United States. This was accomplished by weighing a subset of chicks in natural burrows and boxes on Teuri throughout the season to assess their growth and fledging success, and by taking diet samples of adult birds bringing whole fish back to their chicks to assess diet composition and amount. Similar data was taken by researchers affiliated with PRBO Conservation Science on the Farallon Islands over the same breeding period. Although many analyses remain to be performed on the data, some general outcomes can be drawn. Egg-laying rate, proportion of chicks hatched, and proportion of chicks fledged were all higher on Southeast Farallon Island (SEFI) than on Teuri. Likewise, the diet composition was different. On SEFI, the adults switched from bringing juvenile rockfish to mainly Pacific saury and sablefish, whereas on Teuri, they switched to anchovy. This may be a result of different sampling plans in each location. It could also result from oceanic conditions such as sea surface temperature, which remains to be found for SEFI for this season. Yet another issue could be that the population on Teuri is greater than that on SEFI, and it might have reached its limit in the resources available. This project had great intellectual merit. Although the data collected are not unique, they are part of long-term monitoring studies in both locations which are essential to understanding the ecology of the focal species in its environment, and by extension the ocean as a whole. Long-lived species exhibit high variation in their breeding between years, and seabirds sometimes donÆt breed at all if conditions are unfavorable. This information can be used for management of future conservation of the species. Additionally, there has only been one paper assessing the synchrony of breeding in this species across the Pacific. While it covered the concept well over many years, this project will serve to strengthen the previous paper and lay the groundwork for further collaborations in the future. This holistic approach to scientific work is important to the future of the field. Both Japan and the United States have been doing long-term seabird studies, but there have been few combined efforts to compare notes. This project makes it clear that other colonies in Japan and Russia should be studied and compared to the east side of the Pacific in order to better understand this species and their environment as a whole. Thus, this study melds oceanographic and biological concepts across a large area, unlike previous studies which have often focused in small localized ones. The broader impacts of this study were mainly cultural in nature. Since the methods in collecting data were similar in both places, there was not a lot to learn in that regard, but working across a language barrier and in a different culture made it a learning experience. I worked on my Japanese as we gathered samples and cooked, while my fellow students from Japan were able to practice their English.
